messageBody:
I'm far from a Smalltalk expert, but quite sure that in Smalltalk all fields
are private and methods are public. The language doesn't have any access
modifiers.

Cheers, Ilja

junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:
> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
>> I think Smalltalk does this. If you want to mark methods private, you
>> put them in a protocol that suggests they shouldn't be used directly.
>
> I'm far from a Smalltalk expert, so if somebody is please correct me.
> However, that's not my understanding. What I think is the case is that
> in Smalltalk access protection is object-scoped rather than
> class-scoped. In Smalltalk, any object can see all of its members,
> including members declared private in a superclass, but not the
> private members of its sibling objects and unrelated objects. Thus
> Smalltalk private is a little more like Java protected, though still
> not quite the same thing. However, privacy is still stronger than
> just a suggestion.
>
